issue.title: GitHub Workflows security hardening
issue.body:
This PR adds explicit [permissions section](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-workflows/workflow-syntax-for-github-actions#permissions) to workflows. This is a security best practice because by default workflows run with [extended set of permissions](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/security-guides/automatic-token-authentication#permissions-for-the-github_token) (except from `on: pull_request` [from external forks](https://securitylab.github.com/research/github-actions-preventing-pwn-requests/)). By specifying any permission explicitly all others are set to none. By using the principle of least privilege the damage a compromised workflow can do (because of an [injection](https://securitylab.github.com/research/github-actions-untrusted-input/) or compromised third party tool or action) is restricted.
It is recommended to have [most strict permissions on the top level](https://github.com/ossf/scorecard/blob/main/docs/checks.md#token-permissions) and grant write permissions on [job level](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-jobs/assigning-permissions-to-jobs) case by case.

comment.body: Thanks!

issue.title: Failure to find correct OpenSSL version on Ubuntu 22.04
issue.body:
**Example**

Create a new binary crate with the following `Cargo.toml`:
```
[package]
name = "test-openssl-error"
version = "0.1.0"
edition = "2021"

# See more keys and their definitions at https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/manifest.html

[dependencies]
openssl = "0.10.44"
```

And the following `src/main.rs`:
```
fn main() {
    use openssl::sha;

    let mut hasher = sha::Sha256::new();

    hasher.update(b"Hello, ");
    hasher.update(b"world");

    let hash = hasher.finish();
    println!("Hashed \"Hello, world\" to {:?}", hash);
}
```

Then run `cargo run`. After building, the program terminates with the following, before producing any output. Running the binary directly via `target/debug/test-openssl-error` produces the same error.
```
target/debug/test-openssl-error: error while loading shared libraries: libssl.so.1.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```

My system includes OpenSSL 3, but not 1.1. Somehow, it still selects 1.1 when building. Is there a way to debug why that is?

**OS info**:
```
$ lsb_release -a
LSB Version:	core-11.1.0ubuntu4-noarch:printing-11.1.0ubuntu4-noarch:security-11.1.0ubuntu4-noarch
Distributor ID:	Ubuntu
Description:	Ubuntu 22.04.1 LTS
Release:	22.04
Codename:	jammy
```

```
$ ldd target/debug/test-openssl-error
	linux-vdso.so.1 (0x00007fff87ab6000)
	libssl.so.1.1 => not found
	libcrypto.so.1.1 => not found
	libgcc_s.so.1 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libgcc_s.so.1 (0x00007f27aaff0000)
	libc.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 (0x00007f27aadc8000)
	/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x00007f27ab0a7000)
```

```
$ ldd ~/.cargo/bin/cargo
	linux-vdso.so.1 (0x00007ffe07de1000)
	libgcc_s.so.1 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libgcc_s.so.1 (0x00007f1205460000)
	librt.so.1 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/librt.so.1 (0x00007f120545b000)
	libpthread.so.0 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libpthread.so.0 (0x00007f1205456000)
	libm.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libm.so.6 (0x00007f120536f000)
	libdl.so.2 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libdl.so.2 (0x00007f120536a000)
	libc.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 (0x00007f12043d8000)
	/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x00007f12054c5000)
```

**Related**:
The same seems to happen on arch: https://github.com/pksunkara/cargo-workspaces/issues/81

comment.body: It sounds like you have two OpenSSL installations on the system at the same time. I'm not sure what the easiest way to resolve that would be, but you could e.g. search the filesystem for all copies of `opensslv.h`.

issue.title: Improve documentation and doctests
issue.body:
This PR aims to provide module descriptions for several modules as well as more elaborate examples for modules I've used.

In `openssl::hash` I've moved the examples to functions that the example used (`hash` and `hash_xof`).

I intentionally modified only the examples I touched and left the others alone (not to inflate the diffs).

It's a little bit challenging to come up with a example that is both short and works across all supported OpenSSL flavors. I hope this will provide a nice starting point for people new to the crate as it shows how to build more complex algorithms out of OpenSSL primitives.

Comments and suggestions welcome! Thanks in advance.

comment.body: Done!
Thanks!

issue.body:
I posted this to diesel, but the issues appears to be with r2d2. All the core dumps are r2d2 workers.

Repro (see README for screenshot of one stacktrace): https://github.com/eloff/diesel-segfault

Versions

  -  Rust:
    rustc 1.65.0 (897e37553 2022-11-02)
  -  Diesel:
    2.0.2
 -   Database:
    (PostgreSQL) 15.1 (Ubuntu 15.1-1.pgdg20.04+1)
 -   Operating System
    Ubuntu 20.04 5.15.0-56-generic

I can't reproduce this issue in the docker-compose I provided, just on my Ubuntu 20.04 dev machine. Any idea why that might be? Anything I can test?

comment.body: I'd recommend disabling the atexit callback instead. One way to do this is to call openssl-sys's `init` function at the very beginning of your program.

comment.body:
I have already said that thread-4 is not the one that crashed. I'm not sure how much more explicit I can be.

Thread 1 is trying to take a lock inside of OpenSSL while thread 2 is performing cleanup inside of an atexit handle set by OpenSSL. This is probably https://github.com/openssl/openssl/issues/6214.

> All the core dumps are for r2d2 worker threads.

What specifically do you mean by that? Core dumps are normally a dump of process memory, including *all* threads in the application at the time of the crash.

comment.body:
There is zero unsafe code in this library. It is extremely unlikely the crash is due to a bug in r2d2.

The screenshot of the stacktrace in that repo is of a thread blocked in a futex_wait call, which is not a location would be triggering a segfault. You should find the faulting thread.

pull_request.title: Improve documentation and doctests
pull_request.body:
This PR aims to provide module descriptions for several modules as well as more elaborate examples for modules I've used.

In `openssl::hash` I've moved the examples to functions that the example used (`hash` and `hash_xof`).

I intentionally modified only the examples I touched and left the others alone (not to inflate the diffs).

It's a little bit challenging to come up with a example that is both short and works across all supported OpenSSL flavors. I hope this will provide a nice starting point for people new to the crate as it shows how to build more complex algorithms out of OpenSSL primitives.

Comments and suggestions welcome! Thanks in advance.

issue.title: XCode 14 and older rustup installed rustc versions are incompatible
issue.body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

With the update to xcode 14 older rustc versions installed from `rustup` are failing with an error that looks like this:

```
  = note: ld: in /Users/mitsuhiko/.rustup/toolchains/1.51.0-aarch64-apple-darwin/lib/rustlib/aarch64-apple-darwin/lib/libpanic_unwind-68aa428439efc3d3.rlib(lib.rmeta),
   archive member 'lib.rmeta' with length 33472 is not mach-o or llvm bitcode file
  '/Users/mitsuhiko/.rustup/toolchains/1.51.0-aarch64-apple-darwin/lib/rustlib/aarch64-apple-darwin/lib/libpanic_unwind-68aa428439efc3d3.rlib' for architecture arm64
```

From testing 1.54.0 and 1.56.0 and latest is fine, 1.51 and 1.53 are not.

### Meta
<!--
If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions.
-->

`rustc --version --verbose`:
```
rustc 1.51.0 (2fd73fabe 2021-03-23)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: 2fd73fabe469357a12c2c974c140f67e7cdd76d0
commit-date: 2021-03-23
host: aarch64-apple-darwin
release: 1.51.0
LLVM version: 11.0.1
```

I believe this is related to #103044.

Since those are rather old Rust versions I assume there is not a lot of reason to do something about it, but I figured I report it because I wasn't sure if this was supposed to happen and maybe someone else will also stumble upon it. I noticed it because I had an override set to my MSRV on a library.

comment.body: Also probably related to #104570.

pull_request.title: Allow separate configuration of crate and endpoint versions
pull_request.body:
## Before this PR
The value used for the version of the generated crate and the service version in client endpoint metadata were always the same.

## After this PR
<!-- User-facing outcomes this PR delivers go below -->
==COMMIT_MSG==
The value used for the version of the generated crate can now be set separately from the version used in client endpoint metadata.
==COMMIT_MSG==

We want the endpoint metadata to accurately reflect the version publishing the Conjure IR, but want the crate version to be static (e.g. `0.0.0`) to avoid unnecessarily modifying Cargo.lock.

issue.title: The response isn't returned until the request body is fully written
issue.body:
https://github.com/palantir/conjure-rust-runtime/blob/develop/conjure-runtime/src/service/retry.rs#L241-L242

We join on the response headers future and the request body write futures currently. This means that a request flow that's designed to be full-duplex won't work properly. This is probably a really obscure case but we should do better. We may need to e.g. spawn the request body write off onto a new task if request headers come in before the body write completes.

issue.title: Add a separate `crateVersion` flag
issue.body: When generating a crate, the crate's version is currently pulled from the product version, but that can cause issues where e.g. the lockfile changes on every commit since the version includes a commit hash. We should allow that to be set separately.

pull_request.title: Accept FnMut callbacks
pull_request.body:
The implementation already ensures that there are no concurrent value updates (RefreshHandle::update takes &mut self), but due to how state is shared we need an extra Mutex around each callback.

This is a backwards compatible change since all `Fn`s are also `FnMut`s.

pull_request.title: PKCS#12 create without pkey or cert
pull_request.body:
In the build function, make the cert and key entries Options, which are set to ptr::null_mut when None and otherwise the inner ptr when calling the FFI.

Fixes #1734 

#1721 prevents full testing from crate functions. However, the produced DER-encoded PKCS#12 has been parse by the OpenSSL binary 1.1.1.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -164,17 +164,17 @@ impl Pkcs12Builder {
         self,
         password: &str,
         friendly_name: &str,
-        pkey: &PKeyRef<T>,
-        cert: &X509Ref,
+        pkey: Option<&PKeyRef<T>>,
comment.body: Changing `self` to `mut self` doesn't change the signature of the method - just what the implementation of the method can do with self. It should be fine to have build delegate to build2.

pull_request.title: PKCS#12 create without pkey or cert
pull_request.body:
In the build function, make the cert and key entries Options, which are set to ptr::null_mut when None and otherwise the inner ptr when calling the FFI.

Fixes #1734 

#1721 prevents full testing from crate functions. However, the produced DER-encoded PKCS#12 has been parse by the OpenSSL binary 1.1.1.

issue.title: Make `CipherCtx::cipher_update` more flexible
issue.body:
This change relaxes constraints on the output buffer size when it can be safely determined how many bytes will be put in the output buffer.

For supported cryptographic backends (OpenSSL >= 1.1) the cipher's `num` parameter will be consulted for the number of bytes in the block cache. For unsupported backends the behavior will not change (the code will assume full block in the cache).

For callers that do the check themselves and want to use other backends (e.g. BoringSSL or LibreSSL) and unsafe `unchecked_cipher_update` function is added.

Additionally a `CipherCtx::minimal_output_size` function is added for letting the callers know how big should the output buffer be for the next `cipher_update` call.

Fixes #1729.

See: https://mta.openssl.org/pipermail/openssl-users/2022-November/015623.html

comment.body: I'm happy to cut a new release as well if you'd like.

commits.message:
Make `CipherCtx::cipher_update` more flexible

This change relaxes constraints on the output buffer size when it can be
safely determined how many bytes will be put in the output buffer.

For supported cryptographic backends (OpenSSL >= 1.1) the cipher's `num`
parameter will be consulted for the number of bytes in the block cache.
For unsupported backends the behavior will not change (the code will
assume full block in the cache).

For callers that do the check themselves and want to use other backends
(e.g. BoringSSL or LibreSSL) and unsafe `cipher_update_unchecked`
function is added.

Additionally a `CipherCtx::minimal_output_size` function is added for
letting the callers know how big should the output buffer be for the
next `cipher_update` call.

Fixes #1729.

See: https://mta.openssl.org/pipermail/openssl-users/2022-November/015623.html

issue.title: non-C-like enums are not supported for enum postgres derive
issue.body:
Env:
* rustc 1.65.0 (897e37553 2022-11-02)
* postgres: 0.19.4
* postgres-types: 0.2.4
* postgres-ssl: 0.5.0

I defined such enum:
```rust=
#[derive(FromSql, ToSql)]
pub enum Foo {
    Bar,
    Bzz(i8),
    Qzz(i8),
}
```

It prints error log:
```
error: non-C-like enums are not supported
  --> hi/src/main.rs:17:5
   |
17 |     Bzz(i8),
   |     ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

```

comment.body: I don't believe there is a Postgres type that would correspond to them, which is why the derive doesn't support them.

issue.title: Add macros to more easily define custom (non-Conjure) resources
issue.body: If you need to make an endpoint that isn't definable in Conjure, you currently have to hand-write all of the metadata, parameter conversion, etc. We should add a macro like Dialogue's annotation processors that would allow you to annotate a set of method definitions and have the inner logic automatically created.

pull_request.title: Use async loggers for audit logs
pull_request.body:
## Before this PR
We need to guarantee that audit log entries have been successfully emitted before allowing the associated response to be sent to the client. Previously, this was done by fully serializing each audit log write, flushing each individually. Under higher request volume, this can become a drag on overall throughput.

## After this PR
<!-- User-facing outcomes this PR delivers go below -->
==COMMIT_MSG==
Improved performance of audit logs.
==COMMIT_MSG==

We now use the same async logging infrastructure for audit logs as we have for other log formats. A log entry can now optionally be associated with a `oneshot::Sender<bool>` which is used to notify the log creator when the log has been emitted and if that was successful or not. While requests must still wait on their audit logs to be flushed, we can now batch that flushing process for multiple concurrent requests like we do for request/service/etc logs.

issue.title: GitHub Workflows security hardening
issue.body:
This PR adds explicit [permissions section](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-workflows/workflow-syntax-for-github-actions#permissions) to workflows. This is a security best practice because by default workflows run with [extended set of permissions](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/security-guides/automatic-token-authentication#permissions-for-the-github_token) (except from `on: pull_request` [from external forks](https://securitylab.github.com/research/github-actions-preventing-pwn-requests/)). By specifying any permission explicitly all others are set to none. By using the principle of least privilege the damage a compromised workflow can do (because of an [injection](https://securitylab.github.com/research/github-actions-untrusted-input/) or compromised third party tool or action) is restricted.
It is recommended to have [most strict permissions on the top level](https://github.com/ossf/scorecard/blob/main/docs/checks.md#token-permissions) and grant write permissions on [job level](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-jobs/assigning-permissions-to-jobs) case by case.

comment.body: Thanks!

issue.title: Failure to find correct OpenSSL version on Ubuntu 22.04
issue.body:
**Example**

Create a new binary crate with the following `Cargo.toml`:
```
[package]
name = "test-openssl-error"
version = "0.1.0"
edition = "2021"

# See more keys and their definitions at https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/manifest.html

[dependencies]
openssl = "0.10.44"
```

And the following `src/main.rs`:
```
fn main() {
    use openssl::sha;

    let mut hasher = sha::Sha256::new();

    hasher.update(b"Hello, ");
    hasher.update(b"world");

    let hash = hasher.finish();
    println!("Hashed \"Hello, world\" to {:?}", hash);
}
```

Then run `cargo run`. After building, the program terminates with the following, before producing any output. Running the binary directly via `target/debug/test-openssl-error` produces the same error.
```
target/debug/test-openssl-error: error while loading shared libraries: libssl.so.1.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```

My system includes OpenSSL 3, but not 1.1. Somehow, it still selects 1.1 when building. Is there a way to debug why that is?

**OS info**:
```
$ lsb_release -a
LSB Version:	core-11.1.0ubuntu4-noarch:printing-11.1.0ubuntu4-noarch:security-11.1.0ubuntu4-noarch
Distributor ID:	Ubuntu
Description:	Ubuntu 22.04.1 LTS
Release:	22.04
Codename:	jammy
```

```
$ ldd target/debug/test-openssl-error
	linux-vdso.so.1 (0x00007fff87ab6000)
	libssl.so.1.1 => not found
	libcrypto.so.1.1 => not found
	libgcc_s.so.1 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libgcc_s.so.1 (0x00007f27aaff0000)
	libc.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 (0x00007f27aadc8000)
	/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x00007f27ab0a7000)
```

```
$ ldd ~/.cargo/bin/cargo
	linux-vdso.so.1 (0x00007ffe07de1000)
	libgcc_s.so.1 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libgcc_s.so.1 (0x00007f1205460000)
	librt.so.1 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/librt.so.1 (0x00007f120545b000)
	libpthread.so.0 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libpthread.so.0 (0x00007f1205456000)
	libm.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libm.so.6 (0x00007f120536f000)
	libdl.so.2 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libdl.so.2 (0x00007f120536a000)
	libc.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 (0x00007f12043d8000)
	/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x00007f12054c5000)
```

**Related**:
The same seems to happen on arch: https://github.com/pksunkara/cargo-workspaces/issues/81

comment.body: It sounds like you have two OpenSSL installations on the system at the same time. I'm not sure what the easiest way to resolve that would be, but you could e.g. search the filesystem for all copies of `opensslv.h`.

issue.title: XCode 14 and older rustup installed rustc versions are incompatible
issue.body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

With the update to xcode 14 older rustc versions installed from `rustup` are failing with an error that looks like this:

```
  = note: ld: in /Users/mitsuhiko/.rustup/toolchains/1.51.0-aarch64-apple-darwin/lib/rustlib/aarch64-apple-darwin/lib/libpanic_unwind-68aa428439efc3d3.rlib(lib.rmeta),
   archive member 'lib.rmeta' with length 33472 is not mach-o or llvm bitcode file
  '/Users/mitsuhiko/.rustup/toolchains/1.51.0-aarch64-apple-darwin/lib/rustlib/aarch64-apple-darwin/lib/libpanic_unwind-68aa428439efc3d3.rlib' for architecture arm64
```

From testing 1.54.0 and 1.56.0 and latest is fine, 1.51 and 1.53 are not.

### Meta
<!--
If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions.
-->

`rustc --version --verbose`:
```
rustc 1.51.0 (2fd73fabe 2021-03-23)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: 2fd73fabe469357a12c2c974c140f67e7cdd76d0
commit-date: 2021-03-23
host: aarch64-apple-darwin
release: 1.51.0
LLVM version: 11.0.1
```

I believe this is related to #103044.

Since those are rather old Rust versions I assume there is not a lot of reason to do something about it, but I figured I report it because I wasn't sure if this was supposed to happen and maybe someone else will also stumble upon it. I noticed it because I had an override set to my MSRV on a library.

comment.body: Also probably related to #104570.

## Before this PR
The value used for the version of the generated crate and the service version in client endpoint metadata were always the same.

## After this PR
<!-- User-facing outcomes this PR delivers go below -->
==COMMIT_MSG==
The value used for the version of the generated crate can now be set separately from the version used in client endpoint metadata.
==COMMIT_MSG==

We want the endpoint metadata to accurately reflect the version publishing the Conjure IR, but want the crate version to be static (e.g. `0.0.0`) to avoid unnecessarily modifying Cargo.lock.

issue.title: The response isn't returned until the request body is fully written
issue.body:
https://github.com/palantir/conjure-rust-runtime/blob/develop/conjure-runtime/src/service/retry.rs#L241-L242

We join on the response headers future and the request body write futures currently. This means that a request flow that's designed to be full-duplex won't work properly. This is probably a really obscure case but we should do better. We may need to e.g. spawn the request body write off onto a new task if request headers come in before the body write completes.

issue.title: Add a separate `crateVersion` flag
issue.body: When generating a crate, the crate's version is currently pulled from the product version, but that can cause issues where e.g. the lockfile changes on every commit since the version includes a commit hash. We should allow that to be set separately.

release.body: * Map and subscribe methods now take `FnMut` callbacks rather than just `Fn`.

Merge pull request #13 from palantir/fnmut

Accept FnMut callbacks

pull_request.title: Accept FnMut callbacks
pull_request.body:
The implementation already ensures that there are no concurrent value updates (RefreshHandle::update takes &mut self), but due to how state is shared we need an extra Mutex around each callback.

This is a backwards compatible change since all `Fn`s are also `FnMut`s.

pull_request.title: PKCS#12 create without pkey or cert
pull_request.body:
In the build function, make the cert and key entries Options, which are set to ptr::null_mut when None and otherwise the inner ptr when calling the FFI.

Fixes #1734 

#1721 prevents full testing from crate functions. However, the produced DER-encoded PKCS#12 has been parse by the OpenSSL binary 1.1.1.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -164,17 +164,17 @@ impl Pkcs12Builder {
         self,
         password: &str,
         friendly_name: &str,
-        pkey: &PKeyRef<T>,
-        cert: &X509Ref,
+        pkey: Option<&PKeyRef<T>>,
comment.body: Changing `self` to `mut self` doesn't change the signature of the method - just what the implementation of the method can do with self. It should be fine to have build delegate to build2.

pull_request.title: PKCS#12 create without pkey or cert
pull_request.body:
In the build function, make the cert and key entries Options, which are set to ptr::null_mut when None and otherwise the inner ptr when calling the FFI.

Fixes #1734 

#1721 prevents full testing from crate functions. However, the produced DER-encoded PKCS#12 has been parse by the OpenSSL binary 1.1.1.

issue.title: Make `CipherCtx::cipher_update` more flexible
issue.body:
This change relaxes constraints on the output buffer size when it can be safely determined how many bytes will be put in the output buffer.

For supported cryptographic backends (OpenSSL >= 1.1) the cipher's `num` parameter will be consulted for the number of bytes in the block cache. For unsupported backends the behavior will not change (the code will assume full block in the cache).

For callers that do the check themselves and want to use other backends (e.g. BoringSSL or LibreSSL) and unsafe `unchecked_cipher_update` function is added.

Additionally a `CipherCtx::minimal_output_size` function is added for letting the callers know how big should the output buffer be for the next `cipher_update` call.

Fixes #1729.

See: https://mta.openssl.org/pipermail/openssl-users/2022-November/015623.html

comment.body: I'm happy to cut a new release as well if you'd like.

commits.message:
Make `CipherCtx::cipher_update` more flexible

This change relaxes constraints on the output buffer size when it can be
safely determined how many bytes will be put in the output buffer.

For supported cryptographic backends (OpenSSL >= 1.1) the cipher's `num`
parameter will be consulted for the number of bytes in the block cache.
For unsupported backends the behavior will not change (the code will
assume full block in the cache).

For callers that do the check themselves and want to use other backends
(e.g. BoringSSL or LibreSSL) and unsafe `cipher_update_unchecked`
function is added.

Additionally a `CipherCtx::minimal_output_size` function is added for
letting the callers know how big should the output buffer be for the
next `cipher_update` call.

Fixes #1729.

See: https://mta.openssl.org/pipermail/openssl-users/2022-November/015623.html

issue.title: non-C-like enums are not supported for enum postgres derive
issue.body:
Env:
* rustc 1.65.0 (897e37553 2022-11-02)
* postgres: 0.19.4
* postgres-types: 0.2.4
* postgres-ssl: 0.5.0

I defined such enum:
```rust=
#[derive(FromSql, ToSql)]
pub enum Foo {
    Bar,
    Bzz(i8),
    Qzz(i8),
}
```

It prints error log:
```
error: non-C-like enums are not supported
  --> hi/src/main.rs:17:5
   |
17 |     Bzz(i8),
   |     ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

```

comment.body: I don't believe there is a Postgres type that would correspond to them, which is why the derive doesn't support them.

pull_request.title: Update env_logger requirement from 0.9 to 0.10
pull_request.body:
Updates the requirements on [env_logger](https://github.com/rust-cli/env_logger) to permit the latest version.
Changelog

Sourced from env_logger's changelog.

0.10.0 - 2022-11-24

MSRV changed to 1.60 to hide optional dependencies

Fixes

  • Resolved soundness issue by switching from atty to is-terminal

Breaking Changes

To open room for changing dependencies:

  • Renamed termcolor feature to color
  • Renamed atty feature to auto-color

0.9.3 - 2022-11-07

  • Fix a regression from v0.9.2 where env_logger would fail to compile with the termcolor feature turned off.

0.9.2 - 2022-11-07

  • Fix and un-deprecate Target::Pipe, which was basically not working at all before and deprecated in 0.9.1.

0.9.0 -- 2022-07-14

Breaking Changes

  • Default message format now prints the target instead of the module

Improvements

  • Added a method to print the module instead of the target

issue.title: Add macros to more easily define custom (non-Conjure) resources
issue.body: If you need to make an endpoint that isn't definable in Conjure, you currently have to hand-write all of the metadata, parameter conversion, etc. We should add a macro like Dialogue's annotation processors that would allow you to annotate a set of method definitions and have the inner logic automatically created.

pull_request.title: Use async loggers for audit logs
pull_request.body:
## Before this PR
We need to guarantee that audit log entries have been successfully emitted before allowing the associated response to be sent to the client. Previously, this was done by fully serializing each audit log write, flushing each individually. Under higher request volume, this can become a drag on overall throughput.

## After this PR
<!-- User-facing outcomes this PR delivers go below -->
==COMMIT_MSG==
Improved performance of audit logs.
==COMMIT_MSG==

We now use the same async logging infrastructure for audit logs as we have for other log formats. A log entry can now optionally be associated with a `oneshot::Sender<bool>` which is used to notify the log creator when the log has been emitted and if that was successful or not. While requests must still wait on their audit logs to be flushed, we can now batch that flushing process for multiple concurrent requests like we do for request/service/etc logs.

issue.title: BIO_s_mem on rust
issue.body:
Hi,
Instead of the `TcpStream`, I need a non-blocking memory stream, similar to `BIO_s_mem`. However, this seems to not be implemented in rust?
The reason I need this alternate stream is that I want to use rust-openssl on traffic transmitted over USB instead of TCP.
I have found a somewhat working implementation in cpp using such a memory BIO (and then reading/writing from the bio buffer to usb and vise versa)
Is this also possible using rust-openssl, and if so, how? This crate seems to not implement these BIOs

Thank you!

issue.title: GitHub Workflows security hardening
issue.body:
This PR adds explicit [permissions section](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-workflows/workflow-syntax-for-github-actions#permissions) to workflows. This is a security best practice because by default workflows run with [extended set of permissions](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/security-guides/automatic-token-authentication#permissions-for-the-github_token) (except from `on: pull_request` [from external forks](https://securitylab.github.com/research/github-actions-preventing-pwn-requests/)). By specifying any permission explicitly all others are set to none. By using the principle of least privilege the damage a compromised workflow can do (because of an [injection](https://securitylab.github.com/research/github-actions-untrusted-input/) or compromised third party tool or action) is restricted.
It is recommended to have [most strict permissions on the top level](https://github.com/ossf/scorecard/blob/main/docs/checks.md#token-permissions) and grant write permissions on [job level](https://docs.github.com/en/actions/using-jobs/assigning-permissions-to-jobs) case by case.

comment.body: Thanks!

issue.title: Failure to find correct OpenSSL version on Ubuntu 22.04
issue.body:
**Example**

Create a new binary crate with the following `Cargo.toml`:
```
[package]
name = "test-openssl-error"
version = "0.1.0"
edition = "2021"

# See more keys and their definitions at https://doc.rust-lang.org/cargo/reference/manifest.html

[dependencies]
openssl = "0.10.44"
```

And the following `src/main.rs`:
```
fn main() {
    use openssl::sha;

    let mut hasher = sha::Sha256::new();

    hasher.update(b"Hello, ");
    hasher.update(b"world");

    let hash = hasher.finish();
    println!("Hashed \"Hello, world\" to {:?}", hash);
}
```

Then run `cargo run`. After building, the program terminates with the following, before producing any output. Running the binary directly via `target/debug/test-openssl-error` produces the same error.
```
target/debug/test-openssl-error: error while loading shared libraries: libssl.so.1.1: cannot open shared object file: No such file or directory
```

My system includes OpenSSL 3, but not 1.1. Somehow, it still selects 1.1 when building. Is there a way to debug why that is?

**OS info**:
```
$ lsb_release -a
LSB Version:	core-11.1.0ubuntu4-noarch:printing-11.1.0ubuntu4-noarch:security-11.1.0ubuntu4-noarch
Distributor ID:	Ubuntu
Description:	Ubuntu 22.04.1 LTS
Release:	22.04
Codename:	jammy
```

```
$ ldd target/debug/test-openssl-error
	linux-vdso.so.1 (0x00007fff87ab6000)
	libssl.so.1.1 => not found
	libcrypto.so.1.1 => not found
	libgcc_s.so.1 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libgcc_s.so.1 (0x00007f27aaff0000)
	libc.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 (0x00007f27aadc8000)
	/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x00007f27ab0a7000)
```

```
$ ldd ~/.cargo/bin/cargo
	linux-vdso.so.1 (0x00007ffe07de1000)
	libgcc_s.so.1 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libgcc_s.so.1 (0x00007f1205460000)
	librt.so.1 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/librt.so.1 (0x00007f120545b000)
	libpthread.so.0 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libpthread.so.0 (0x00007f1205456000)
	libm.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libm.so.6 (0x00007f120536f000)
	libdl.so.2 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libdl.so.2 (0x00007f120536a000)
	libc.so.6 => /lib/x86_64-linux-gnu/libc.so.6 (0x00007f12043d8000)
	/lib64/ld-linux-x86-64.so.2 (0x00007f12054c5000)
```

**Related**:
The same seems to happen on arch: https://github.com/pksunkara/cargo-workspaces/issues/81

comment.body: It sounds like you have two OpenSSL installations on the system at the same time. I'm not sure what the easiest way to resolve that would be, but you could e.g. search the filesystem for all copies of `opensslv.h`.

issue.title: XCode 14 and older rustup installed rustc versions are incompatible
issue.body:
<!--
Thank you for filing a bug report! 🐛 Please provide a short summary of the bug,
along with any information you feel relevant to replicating the bug.
-->

With the update to xcode 14 older rustc versions installed from `rustup` are failing with an error that looks like this:

```
  = note: ld: in /Users/mitsuhiko/.rustup/toolchains/1.51.0-aarch64-apple-darwin/lib/rustlib/aarch64-apple-darwin/lib/libpanic_unwind-68aa428439efc3d3.rlib(lib.rmeta),
   archive member 'lib.rmeta' with length 33472 is not mach-o or llvm bitcode file
  '/Users/mitsuhiko/.rustup/toolchains/1.51.0-aarch64-apple-darwin/lib/rustlib/aarch64-apple-darwin/lib/libpanic_unwind-68aa428439efc3d3.rlib' for architecture arm64
```

From testing 1.54.0 and 1.56.0 and latest is fine, 1.51 and 1.53 are not.

### Meta
<!--
If you're using the stable version of the compiler, you should also check if the
bug also exists in the beta or nightly versions.
-->

`rustc --version --verbose`:
```
rustc 1.51.0 (2fd73fabe 2021-03-23)
binary: rustc
commit-hash: 2fd73fabe469357a12c2c974c140f67e7cdd76d0
commit-date: 2021-03-23
host: aarch64-apple-darwin
release: 1.51.0
LLVM version: 11.0.1
```

I believe this is related to #103044.

Since those are rather old Rust versions I assume there is not a lot of reason to do something about it, but I figured I report it because I wasn't sure if this was supposed to happen and maybe someone else will also stumble upon it. I noticed it because I had an override set to my MSRV on a library.

comment.body: Also probably related to #104570.

pull_request.title: Allow separate configuration of crate and endpoint versions
pull_request.body:
## Before this PR
The value used for the version of the generated crate and the service version in client endpoint metadata were always the same.

## After this PR
<!-- User-facing outcomes this PR delivers go below -->
==COMMIT_MSG==
The value used for the version of the generated crate can now be set separately from the version used in client endpoint metadata.
==COMMIT_MSG==

We want the endpoint metadata to accurately reflect the version publishing the Conjure IR, but want the crate version to be static (e.g. `0.0.0`) to avoid unnecessarily modifying Cargo.lock.

commits.message: Allow separate configuration of crate and endpoint versions

issue.title: The response isn't returned until the request body is fully written
issue.body:
https://github.com/palantir/conjure-rust-runtime/blob/develop/conjure-runtime/src/service/retry.rs#L241-L242

We join on the response headers future and the request body write futures currently. This means that a request flow that's designed to be full-duplex won't work properly. This is probably a really obscure case but we should do better. We may need to e.g. spawn the request body write off onto a new task if request headers come in before the body write completes.

issue.title: Add a separate `crateVersion` flag
issue.body: When generating a crate, the crate's version is currently pulled from the product version, but that can cause issues where e.g. the lockfile changes on every commit since the version includes a commit hash. We should allow that to be set separately.

release.body: * Map and subscribe methods now take `FnMut` callbacks rather than just `Fn`.

Merge pull request #13 from palantir/fnmut

Accept FnMut callbacks

pull_request.title: Accept FnMut callbacks
pull_request.body:
The implementation already ensures that there are no concurrent value updates (RefreshHandle::update takes &mut self), but due to how state is shared we need an extra Mutex around each callback.

This is a backwards compatible change since all `Fn`s are also `FnMut`s.

pull_request.title: PKCS#12 create without pkey or cert
pull_request.body:
In the build function, make the cert and key entries Options, which are set to ptr::null_mut when None and otherwise the inner ptr when calling the FFI.

Fixes #1734 

#1721 prevents full testing from crate functions. However, the produced DER-encoded PKCS#12 has been parse by the OpenSSL binary 1.1.1.

comment.diff_hunk:
@@ -164,17 +164,17 @@ impl Pkcs12Builder {
         self,
         password: &str,
         friendly_name: &str,
-        pkey: &PKeyRef<T>,
-        cert: &X509Ref,
+        pkey: Option<&PKeyRef<T>>,
comment.body: Changing `self` to `mut self` doesn't change the signature of the method - just what the implementation of the method can do with self. It should be fine to have build delegate to build2.

pull_request.title: PKCS#12 create without pkey or cert
pull_request.body:
In the build function, make the cert and key entries Options, which are set to ptr::null_mut when None and otherwise the inner ptr when calling the FFI.

Fixes #1734 

#1721 prevents full testing from crate functions. However, the produced DER-encoded PKCS#12 has been parse by the OpenSSL binary 1.1.1.

issue.title: Make `CipherCtx::cipher_update` more flexible
issue.body:
This change relaxes constraints on the output buffer size when it can be safely determined how many bytes will be put in the output buffer.

For supported cryptographic backends (OpenSSL >= 1.1) the cipher's `num` parameter will be consulted for the number of bytes in the block cache. For unsupported backends the behavior will not change (the code will assume full block in the cache).

For callers that do the check themselves and want to use other backends (e.g. BoringSSL or LibreSSL) and unsafe `unchecked_cipher_update` function is added.

Additionally a `CipherCtx::minimal_output_size` function is added for letting the callers know how big should the output buffer be for the next `cipher_update` call.

Fixes #1729.

See: https://mta.openssl.org/pipermail/openssl-users/2022-November/015623.html

commits.message:
Make `CipherCtx::cipher_update` more flexible

This change relaxes constraints on the output buffer size when it can be
safely determined how many bytes will be put in the output buffer.

For supported cryptographic backends (OpenSSL >= 1.1) the cipher's `num`
parameter will be consulted for the number of bytes in the block cache.
For unsupported backends the behavior will not change (the code will
assume full block in the cache).

For callers that do the check themselves and want to use other backends
(e.g. BoringSSL or LibreSSL) and unsafe `cipher_update_unchecked`
function is added.

Additionally a `CipherCtx::minimal_output_size` function is added for
letting the callers know how big should the output buffer be for the
next `cipher_update` call.

Fixes #1729.

See: https://mta.openssl.org/pipermail/openssl-users/2022-November/015623.html

issue.title: non-C-like enums are not supported for enum postgres derive
issue.body:
Env:
* rustc 1.65.0 (897e37553 2022-11-02)
* postgres: 0.19.4
* postgres-types: 0.2.4
* postgres-ssl: 0.5.0

I defined such enum:
```rust=
#[derive(FromSql, ToSql)]
pub enum Foo {
    Bar,
    Bzz(i8),
    Qzz(i8),
}
```

It prints error log:
```
error: non-C-like enums are not supported
  --> hi/src/main.rs:17:5
   |
17 |     Bzz(i8),
   |     ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

```

comment.body: I don't believe there is a Postgres type that would correspond to them, which is why the derive doesn't support them.

pull_request.body:
Updates the requirements on [env_logger](https://github.com/rust-cli/env_logger) to permit the latest version.
Changelog

Sourced from env_logger's changelog.

0.10.0 - 2022-11-24

MSRV changed to 1.60 to hide optional dependencies

Fixes

  • Resolved soundness issue by switching from atty to is-terminal

Breaking Changes

To open room for changing dependencies:

  • Renamed termcolor feature to color
  • Renamed atty feature to auto-color

0.9.3 - 2022-11-07

  • Fix a regression from v0.9.2 where env_logger would fail to compile with the termcolor feature turned off.

0.9.2 - 2022-11-07

  • Fix and un-deprecate Target::Pipe, which was basically not working at all before and deprecated in 0.9.1.

0.9.0 -- 2022-07-14

Breaking Changes

  • Default message format now prints the target instead of the module

Improvements

  • Added a method to print the module instead of the target

issue.title: Add macros to more easily define custom (non-Conjure) resources
issue.body: If you need to make an endpoint that isn't definable in Conjure, you currently have to hand-write all of the metadata, parameter conversion, etc. We should add a macro like Dialogue's annotation processors that would allow you to annotate a set of method definitions and have the inner logic automatically created.

pull_request.title: Use async loggers for audit logs
pull_request.body:
## Before this PR
We need to guarantee that audit log entries have been successfully emitted before allowing the associated response to be sent to the client. Previously, this was done by fully serializing each audit log write, flushing each individually. Under higher request volume, this can become a drag on overall throughput.

## After this PR
<!-- User-facing outcomes this PR delivers go below -->
==COMMIT_MSG==
Improved performance of audit logs.
==COMMIT_MSG==

We now use the same async logging infrastructure for audit logs as we have for other log formats. A log entry can now optionally be associated with a `oneshot::Sender<bool>` which is used to notify the log creator when the log has been emitted and if that was successful or not. While requests must still wait on their audit logs to be flushed, we can now batch that flushing process for multiple concurrent requests like we do for request/service/etc logs.

issue.title: non-C-like enums are not supported for enum postgres derive
issue.body:
Env:
* rustc 1.65.0 (897e37553 2022-11-02)
* postgres: 0.19.4
* postgres-types: 0.2.4
* postgres-ssl: 0.5.0

I defined such enum:
```rust=
#[derive(FromSql, ToSql)]
pub enum Foo {
    Bar,
    Bzz(i8),
    Qzz(i8),
}
```

It prints error log:
```
error: non-C-like enums are not supported
  --> hi/src/main.rs:17:5
   |
17 |     Bzz(i8),
   |     ^^^^^^^^^^^^^^

```

comment.body: What Postgres type would they correspond to?

issue.title: BIO_s_mem on rust
issue.body:
Hi,
Instead of the `TcpStream`, I need a non-blocking memory stream, similar to `BIO_s_mem`. However, this seems to not be implemented in rust?
The reason I need this alternate stream is that I want to use rust-openssl on traffic transmitted over USB instead of TCP.
I have found a somewhat working implementation in cpp using such a memory BIO (and then reading/writing from the bio buffer to usb and vise versa)
Is this also possible using rust-openssl, and if so, how? This crate seems to not implement these BIOs

Thank you!
